name: History of the United States of America Part 4 Quiz | History | 10 Questions

questions.text: As part of the Civil Rights Movement, Rosa Parks protested segregation by refusing to give up her bus seat to a white man in 1955. Where did this event occur?
questions.explanation:
Montgomery, Alabama.

	In 1956 the Supreme Court declared segregation on buses to be unconstitutional with the case of Browder v. Gayle.

questions.text: Citizens of Washington D.C. were originally unable to perform a specific task that the Constitution allowed the states to do. The 23rd Amendment changed this. What did this amendment provide D.C. with?
questions.explanation:
Electoral votes.

	Until this amendment was passed in 1961, citizens of D.C. were not allowed to vote in national elections. D.C. participated in the 1964 presidential election and is allowed up to three electoral votes due to its size and population.

questions.text: In 1963 President JFK became the fourth U.S. president to be assassinated in office. He was the youngest U.S. president at the time of his election. (Theodore Roosevelt was younger on becoming president in 1901, but as vice-president at the time of the assassination of William McKinley he succeeded to the presidency. He was older than Kennedy when he won his first presidential election in 1904). Who was JFK's assassin?
questions.explanation:
Lee Harvey Oswald.

	JFK became the nation's 35th president at the age of 43. Oswald was killed before he was able to have a trial. There are many theories that the president's assassination was a conspiracy, one of the most famous being the Golden Bullet Theory.

questions.text: In 1972 America launched its sixth mission to send people to the moon. The name of this mission was Apollo 17. Who was the commander of this mission, who had been on two previous spaceflights?
questions.explanation:
Eugene Cernan.

	Apollo 17 launched on December 7, 1972 and returned after a twelve day mission. At one stage there were plans for Apollo 18 but these were canceled in 1970.

questions.text: In 1974, due to his alleged participation in the Watergate Scandal, President Nixon became the first US president to resign from office. Who became president after his resignation?
questions.explanation:
Ford.

	Nixon was accused of hiding evidence of a break in and robbery at Watergate. Ford pardoned Nixon of all crimes he may have committed as president.

questions.text: In 1981 President Ronald Reagan appointed the first female US Supreme Court Justice. What was her name?
questions.explanation:
Sandra Day O'Connor.

	Sandra Day O'Connor remained in this position until 2006. In 1993 President Clinton appointed Ruth Bader Ginsburg as the first Jewish female justice.

questions.text: In 1991 the internet becomes a public service worldwide. Who is considered the Internet's inventor?
questions.explanation:
Tim Berners-Lee.

	Before the internet became a world wide product it was used as a form of communication for the military. In search of scientific improvement, President Eisenhower helped to start the internet's development when he initiated the Advanced Research Projects Agency (ARPA) almost immediately after the Soviets launched Sputnik I.

questions.text: In 1994 an agreement was signed between the US, Canada, and Mexico to establish trade regulation between these countries. What is the acronym for this agreement?
questions.explanation:
NAFTA.

	NAFTA stands for the North American Free Trade Agreement. This agreement replaced the Canada-United States Free Trade Agreement that was already in effect at the time and was now extended to include Mexico.

questions.text: In 2001 one of the world's most devastating terrorist attacks occurred on September 11th. Terrorists flew planes into three locations. Which of the following was NOT hit by one of the planes.
questions.explanation:
White House.

	These attacks were performed by the terrorist organization known as Al-Qaeda. Its leader was Osama Bin Laden, who remained leader until he was killed in 2011.

questions.text: In 2008 president Barack Obama became the first African American President. Who did he run against on election day in 2008?
questions.explanation:
John McCain.

	President Obama became the nation's 44th president and was reelected in 2012. He chose Joe Biden to be his vice president.
